channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Russians Fleeing the Draft Find an Unlikely Haven in Kyrgyzstan
item.description: Tens of thousands of men have ended up in places like Kyrgyzstan, a former Soviet territory, that normally see few refugees but are willing to take them.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yuri, a 36-year-old artist from Siberia, took three days to get by bus and train to Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan, where he now lives in a 20-bed hostel room.

item.title: OPEC and Russia to Meet, With a Big Cut in Oil Output on the Table
item.description: Saudi Arabia appears determined to bolster prices and continue coordinating with Russia during the Ukraine war.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Lukoil refinery in Italy last month. Italy has increased its imports of Russian crude despite the European Union’s efforts to cut ties to Russian energy.

item.title: Talk of ‘Civil War,’ Ignited by Mar-a-Lago Search, Is Flaring Online
item.description: Mentions in Twitter posts on the right have spiked during major political news events, and experts worry the overheated language will spread as the midterm elections draw near.
item.dc:creator: Ken Bensinger and Sheera Frenkel
item.media:credit: Marco Bello/Reuters
item.media:description: Trump supporters outside Mar-a-Lago after the F.B.I.’s search in August. More Americans are anticipating, or even welcoming, the possibility of sustained political violence, researchers studying extremism say.

item.title: Trump Asks Supreme Court to Intervene in Review of Mar-a-Lago Records
item.description: In earlier cases, the justices have ruled against the former president when he sought to shield his financial and presidential records from prosecutors and congressional investigators.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak and Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump appealed on narrow grounds, not asking the Supreme Court to overturn the most important part of an appeals court’s decision.

item.title: Aaron Judge Hits Homer 62, Passing Roger Maris for AL Record
item.description: A blast against Texas vaulted Judge past Roger Maris for the American League’s single-season record, rekindling enthusiasm for a milestone spoiled by the steroid era.
item.dc:creator: David Waldstein
item.media:credit: Nathan Hunsinger for The New York Times
item.media:description: With a 391-foot blast against the Texas Rangers on Tuesday, Aaron Judge of the Yankees reached 62 home runs for the season, setting a new single-season American League record.

item.title: After Hitting No. 62, Aaron Judge Acknowledges Pressure of Chase
item.description: “The past couple games I’d look up and it’s the seventh inning and go, ‘Dang, I only got one more at-bat. We got to figure this out.’”
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:credit: Nathan Hunsinger for The New York Times
item.media:description: A relaxed Aaron Judge discussed his achievement in a news conference after the game.

item.title: Where Will Judge’s 62nd Home Run Fall in a Record Book of Asterisks?
item.description: The so-called steroid era complicates discussion of Aaron Judge’s 62-homer season, but as with other issues, it is a cause for explanation rather than the rewriting of history.
item.dc:creator: Scott Miller
item.media:credit: Nathan Hunsinger for The New York Times
item.media:description: Aaron Judge has hit more home runs than any other American League hitter, but Barry Bonds still holds M.L.B.’s overall record with 73.

item.title: Elon Musk’s Twitter Will Be a Wild Ride
item.description: His deal to buy the company is back on. Here are six predictions about Twitter under Musk’s control, if it happens.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose
item.media:credit: Michael Gonzalez/Getty Images
item.media:description: Changes are likely to come to Twitter if and when Elon Musk, seen here in August, becomes the owner of the company.

item.title: U.S. Aims to Turn Taiwan Into Giant Weapons Depot
item.description: Officials say Taiwan needs to become a “porcupine” with enough weapons to hold out if the Chinese military blockades and invades it, even if Washington decides to send troops.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taiwanese military exercises in July. The United States has approved several weapons packages for the island.

item.title: Nobel Prize in Chemistry Is Awarded to 3 Scientists for Work ‘Snapping Molecules Together’
item.description: Carolyn R. Bertozzi, Morten Meldal and K. Barry Sharpless were honored for their work in click chemistry, or linking molecules together.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht, Euan Ward and Oliver Whang

item.title: After the Storm, the Mold: Warming Is Worsening Another Costly Disaster
item.description: Mold in homes is a costly crisis that often accompanies hurricanes and flooding, and climate change is amplifying the rain that feeds outbreaks.
item.dc:creator: Winston Choi-Schagrin and Emily Kask
item.media:credit: Emily Kask for The New York Times

item.title: The Spy Who Escaped the Eye of the Storm
item.description: Porter J. Goss, the former C.I.A. director and a longtime Florida congressman, was one of the founding fathers of devastated Sanibel.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: Johnny Milano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers search for people who were unable to evacuate from Sanibel Island after Hurricane Ian swept through.

item.title: Eviction Looming For California Scofflaw And His Two Acres of Land
item.description: David Lee Hoffman has been fighting a local government in California for decades to keep his eccentric home and way of living intact.
item.dc:creator: Achy Obejas
item.media:credit: Matthew Millman for The New York Times
item.media:description: David Lee Hoffman has spent decades fighting Marin County, Calif., for the right to do as he wishes with his property. He could soon be removed.

item.title: How to Time Your Leaf-Peeping Trip This Fall
item.description: From New England to California, and points in between, the symphony of colors that accompanies the arrival of a snap in the air is playing out differently in 2022.
item.dc:creator: Debra Kamin
item.media:credit: Stacey Cramp for The New York Times
item.media:description: AccuWeather predicts that peak colors in places like Maine, New Hampshire, Vermont and northern New York will come late this year, in mid- to late October. Above, fall in Grafton Notch State Park, Maine.

item.title: Nuclear Annihilation Is a Threat Again
item.description: The Cuban missile crisis has been viewed as the defining confrontation of the modern age. The war in Ukraine presents perils of at least equal magnitude.
item.dc:creator: Michael Dobbs
item.media:credit: Cecil Stoughton/White House Photographs, via John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum
item.media:description: President John Kennedy and national security officials during the Cuban missile crisis in October 1962.

item.title: Education Divides Everything, Including Life and Death
item.description: “There are two Americas now: one with a B.A. and one without.”
item.dc:creator: Thomas B. Edsall
item.media:credit: Damon Winter/The New York Times

item.title: What Do the Physical Costs of Pregnancy Mean for the Abortion Debate? //alt: Pregnancy Can Be an Ordeal. What Does that Mean for the Abortion Debate?
item.description: On the argument that childbearing’s trauma justifies abortion rights.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat
item.media:credit: Damon Winter/The New York Times

item.title: Where Red and Blue Make Green
item.description: Part of the resistance or part of the problem? It doesn’t matter: These lawyers are part of the gang.
item.dc:creator: Megan K. Stack
item.category: Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP
item.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times; image by Brian A Jackson, via Getty Images

item.title: Brazil’s Election on Sunday Showed That “Bolsonarismo” Is Here to Stay
item.description: Support for Brazil’s president is spread across the country.
item.dc:creator: Andre Pagliarini
item.media:credit: Andressa Anholete/Getty Images

item.title: Loretta Lynn Could Convince Me of Anything
item.description: She was so committed to the rigors of loving herself that she suffered no one.
item.dc:creator: Hanif Abdurraqib

item.title: What a Conservative Therapist Thinks About U.S. Politics and Mental Health
item.description: Conservatives need mental health help, too, but do they need to get it from someone who shares their worldview?
item.dc:creator: Meghan Daum
item.media:credit: David Williams for The New York Times

item.title: The First Global Deflation Has Begun, and It’s Unclear Just How Painful It Will Be
item.description: We now find ourselves in the midst of the most comprehensive tightening of monetary policy the world has seen.
item.dc:creator: Adam Tooze
item.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times; images via Getty Images

item.title: Where defending nature can be deadly
item.description: No region is more dangerous for environmentalists than Latin America. We explain why it’s getting worse.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Andreoni
item.media:credit: Ueslei Marcelino/Reuters
item.media:description: Indigenous land defenders detained a logger in Brazil, by many measures the world’s most dangerous country for environmental activists, in 2019.

item.title: Poll Update: Republicans Gain in the Senate
item.description: A closer look at Pennsylvania and Nevada, and some Democratic leads that seem vulnerable.
item.dc:creator: Nate Cohn
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier/Reuters
item.media:description: John Fetterman, the Democratic Senate candidate in Pennsylvania, has seen his lead in the polls dwindle, perhaps because Republican voters are coming home to their party.

item.title: Modern Love Podcast: One Last Haircut
item.description: A man comes out to his wife — and breaks apart their family. Fifteen years later, we check back in.
item.media:credit: Brian Rea

item.title: Scary Stories
item.description: It’s Spooky Season. What are your favorite scary books, movies, TV shows and podcasts?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network
item.media:credit: Siobhan Gallagher

item.title: Prosecutions for Fire Safety Violations Dropped by 98% in New York City
item.description: The dramatic decline has prompted concerns about safety just months after the city’s deadliest blaze in decades.
item.dc:creator: Mihir Zaveri
item.media:credit: David Dee Delgado for The New York Times
item.media:description: Firefighters surveying the Twin Parks North West building in the Bronx where 17 people died in a fire in January.

item.title: ‘Defund the SEC’ Becomes a Rallying Cry on Trump’s Social Media Site
item.description: The nation’s top securities regulator has been investigating the Trump SPAC deal for a year. Some small investors are upset.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Goldstein
item.media:credit: Todd Anderson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump’s social media company was created by associates shortly after he lost the 2020 election.

item.title: Jeffrey Dahmer Series on Netflix Revisits a Painful Past
item.description: A Netflix series about the infamous Milwaukee serial killer aims to tell the gruesome story through the experience of his victims. Those who remember them say that attempt failed.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin

item.title: When You Step Inside This Lab, You Must Whip It
item.description: By studying the movements of volunteers cracking bullwhips, scientists sought to understand the manipulation of nonrigid and wobbly objects.
item.dc:creator: Carolyn Wilke

item.title: Your Medical Test Results Are Available. But Do You Want to View Them?
item.description: The 21st Century Cures Act gave patients easy access to their health information. Now, some diagnoses delivered without context are causing high anxiety.
item.dc:creator: Danielle Friedman
item.media:credit: Diana Ejaita

item.title: Is Teeth Whitening Safe? What to Know and Products to Use
item.description: Many products claim to lighten and brighten your teeth. Here’s what the experts say about them.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Seo
item.media:credit: Ryan Jenq for The New York Times. Prop Stylist: Laura Woolf

item.title: How To Make Friends As An Adult
item.description: A friendship expert shares strategies for finding connection in a lonely, disconnected world.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson
item.category: Platonic: How the Science of Attachment Can Help You Make -- and Keep -- Friends (Book)
item.media:credit: Illustration by Vanessa Saba; Photographs by Getty Images

item.title: How to Give Constructive Feedback
item.description: Experts say fear keeps us from sharing constructive feedback, but here’s how — and why — you should speak up anyway.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Nicolas Ortega

item.title: Pain in Children is Often Ignored. For Children of Color, It’s Even Worse.
item.description: Racial differences in medical care are part of a theme experts are seeing “over and over” again.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Rabkin Peachman
item.media:credit: Mikyung Lee

item.title: In ‘Smile,’ Why the Grins Are So Grim
item.description: Parker Finn, the director of the new horror film where characters smile before death, said the secret to making a smile creepy was in the eyes.
item.dc:creator: Erik Piepenburg

item.title: How to Solve Intermediate Crosswords
item.description: Moving up to the Wednesday and Thursday puzzles.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
